title: 103_hr187
content: The Act is titled the "American Samoa Study Commission Act" and includes Congressional findings. The Congress finds that American Samoa's status as an unorganized and unincorporated territory of the United States needs a comprehensive study to determine its political relationship compared to other territories. American Samoa's political status and relationship with the United States, including treaties of cession and trust obligations, significantly impact its economic and social needs. Additionally, a comprehensive study is needed for Swains Island. The "American Samoa Study Commission" is established to address the territory's political status and relationship with the United States, including treaties and trust obligations. The commission is tasked with conducting a comprehensive study, including Swains Island. The Commission is responsible for studying American Samoa's historical and present political status and relationship with the United States, including events leading to cession and treaties affecting its status. It will also determine the nature of American Samoa's relationship compared to other arrangements like commonwealth and free association. The Commission is tasked with studying American Samoa's political status and relationship with the United States, including trust obligations and economic impacts. They are required to consult with American Samoans in carrying out their duties. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 5 members appointed by different authorities, with each member serving for the life of the Commission. Members are paid $150 per day, subject to availability of funds. Members of the Commission are paid $150 per day for their duties, with travel expenses covered. Full-time federal employees cannot receive additional compensation for their service on the Commission. A quorum consists of 3 members, and the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are appointed positions. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson of the Commission are elected by the members. The Secretary of the Interior must call the initial meeting within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and subsequent meetings can be called by the Chairperson or a majority of the members. SEC. 6. STAFF AND SUPPORT SERVICES. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, who can appoint personnel and set pay. The Director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Chairperson can also procure temporary experts and consultants. The Commission may procure temporary services at rates not exceeding $150 per day. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services upon request. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Required hearings must be conducted in specific locations in American Samoa, while additional hearings may be held in the United States. Public notice of hearings must be provided. The Commission may hold hearings in specific locations, including American Samoa, to obtain public participation. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can request official data from Federal agencies to carry out its duties. The Commission can hold hearings in various locations for public participation and request data from Federal agencies. The Commission is allowed to use the United States mails like other Federal agencies, except for information prohibited by law. SEC. 8. REPORTS. The Commission is required to prepare and publish a draft report within one year of the enactment of the Act, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. This report must be distributed to relevant agencies and made available to the public upon request. The Commission will also solicit written comments on the draft report from these agencies and other individuals. Additionally, a final report must be published within nine months of the initial report. The Commission is required to submit a final report to the President and Congress, including findings, recommendations for legislative and administrative actions, and copies of all written comments received. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. The term "American Samoan" is defined as "native American Samoan" in Public Law 100-571. The term "Commission" refers to the American Samoa Study Commission. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $200,000 is authorized for this Act. SEC. 11. TERMINATION. The Commission will end within 60 days after submitting its final report.
